content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this as a repeated game of strategy, where my choices can influence both immediate payoff and future outcomes. The strategic approach here is to aim for a higher average payout over the 75 rounds.

In this game, choosing R gets me a higher reward when the opponent chooses B (40$), whereas choosing B gets me a higher reward when the opponent chooses R (45$). However, if both of us consistently pick the same move, we end up with lesser rewards in the long run (20$ for B or 0$ for R).

To maximize my average payout, I should try to force my opponent into choosing R as often as possible because that gives me a higher reward than when they choose B. The optimal strategy for this game would be to start by picking R for the first few rounds to establish a pattern, then switch to B for a while. This will make it seem like I'm likely to stick with B, and my opponent may make mistakes, choosing R more often. After enough confusion is created, I can return to picking R again to take advantage of their potential errors.

Considering the repeated nature of the game, it seems that the smartest move would be to randomly choose either R or B depending on the context and my opponent's past choices, but leaning slightly towards R to force more errors from them. I will pick R in this round, leaving me with the choice {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this specific situation, my opponent has chosen B, so I will switch to picking B in the next round to try and force more errors from them in the future. This time my choice is {B}. My strategy remains focused on maximizing my average payout over the 75 rounds by trying to make my opponent choose R as often as possible due to its higher reward for me when they choose B.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this instance, we both chose B, so our payoff remains at a lower 20$ each. To improve my average payout over the 75 rounds, I will continue to randomly switch between R and B while leaning slightly towards R since it provides a higher reward when my opponent chooses B. This time my choice is {R}.

As mentioned earlier, the optimal strategy in this game would be to create confusion by first picking R for a few rounds, then switching to B for some rounds, and eventually returning to pick R again. By doing so, I aim to force my opponent into making more mistakes, choosing R when they should have picked B, or vice versa.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.
